analysis.noAnalysisDesc: Start analyzing your skin to track your history and improvements
analysis.disclaimerText: This analysis is for informational purposes only and should not replace professional medical advice. Always consult a qualified healthcare provider for diagnosis and treatment.
analysis.Acne_desc: A chronic inflammatory skin condition characterized by clogged hair follicles. It presents as pimples, blackheads, whiteheads, or cysts, primarily on the face, shoulders, chest, and back.
analysis.Actinic_Keratosis_desc: A rough, scaly patch on the skin caused by years of sun exposure. It is considered precancerous because it can potentially develop into squamous cell carcinoma if left untreated.
analysis.Drug_Eruption_desc: A drug eruption is an adverse skin reaction, such as a rash or hives, triggered by the body's immune or chemical response to a specific medication.
analysis.Eczema_desc: Also known as atopic dermatitis, this is a condition that makes the skin red, itchy, and inflamed. It damages the skin barrier function, making the skin more sensitive and prone to dryness.
analysis.Psoriasis_desc: An autoimmune disease that accelerates the growth cycle of skin cells. This causes cells to build up rapidly on the surface of the skin, forming thick, silvery scales and itchy, dry, red patches.
analysis.Rosacea_desc: A chronic skin condition that affects the face, causing redness, flushing, and visible blood vessels. It can also produce small, red, pus-filled bumps often mistaken for acne.
analysis.Seborrh_Keratoses_desc: A common, non-cancerous (benign) skin growth. They often appear as brown, black, or light tan growths on the face, chest, shoulders, or back and have a waxy, scaly, 'stuck-on' appearance.
analysis.Sun_Sunlight_Damage_desc: General cutaneous damage (photoaging) caused by prolonged exposure to ultraviolet (UV) radiation. Signs include leathery skin texture, wrinkles, and hyperpigmentation (sunspots or age spots).
analysis.Tinea_desc: The technical term for a group of fungal skin infections, commonly known as ringworm. Depending on the location, it is referred to as athlete's foot, jock itch, or ringworm of the body.
analysis.Warts_desc: Small, grainy skin growths caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV). They feel rough to the touch and are contagious, spreading through skin-to-skin contact.
analysis.Oily_desc: A skin type characterized by overactive sebaceous glands producing excess sebum. It often appears shiny or greasy, has enlarged pores, and is more prone to acne breakouts, blackheads, and blemishes.
analysis.Normal_desc: Well-balanced skin that is neither too oily nor too dry. It has a smooth texture, fine pores, good blood circulation, and lacks severe sensitivity or visible blemishes. It represents a healthy barrier function.
analysis.Dry_desc: A skin type characterized by a lack of sufficient moisture and natural oils (lipids). It often feels tight, rough, or itchy, appears dull or flaky, and is more susceptible to fine lines and irritation due to a compromised skin barrier.
analysis.noFaceDetectedMsg: We could not find a face in the image. Please ensure your face is well-lit and centered.

onboarding.welcomeSubtitle: Your personalized skin care journey starts here. Let's help you find the perfect products for your skin.

onboarding.feature2: Find products that match your skin type and concerns
onboarding.feature3: Avoid ingredients that may harm your skin
onboarding.allergyInfo: Help us personalize your experience by letting us know about any allergies or sensitivities. We'll exclude products with these ingredients from your recommendations.
